S3.T1.caption: Table 1: State-of-the-art comparison on OK-VQA dataset. The middle column lists the external knowledge sources, if any, used in each VQA system. The rows in the middle part list the method based on pre-trained model.
S3.T1.table:
Method       Knowledge Resources       Accuracy
      ArticleNet (AN) [29]       Wikipedia       5.28
      Q-only [29]       —       14.93
      BAN [18]       —       25.17
       +AN [29]       Wikipedia       25.61
       + KG-AUG [21]       Wikipedia + ConceptNet       26.71
      MUTAN [6]       —       26.41
       + AN [29]       Wikipedia       27.84
      Mucko [60]       ConceptNet       29.20
      GRUC [54]       ConceptNet       29.87
      KM4 [58]       multimodal knowledge from OK-VQA       31.32
      ViLBERT [25]       —       31.35
      LXMERT [44]       —       32.04
      KRISP(w/o mm pre.) [28]       DBpedia + ConceptNet + VisualGenome + haspartKB       32.31
      KRISP(w/ mm pre.) [28]       DBpedia + ConceptNet + VisualGenome + haspartKB       38.90
      ConceptBert [12]       ConceptNet       33.66
      Knowledge is Power [59]       YAGO3       39.24

references: Comparison on OK-VQA: Table 1 shows the comparison results with state-of-the-art models, including knowledge graph based approaches [60, 54, 12, 59], unstructured-knowledge based approaches [29], multi-source knowledge based hybrid approaches [21, 28], implicit knowledge based pre-training approaches [44, 25], and the multimodal knowledge based approach [58]. Meanwhile, we also compare with traditional VQA methods [18, 6].

In Table 1, we compare the model size of MuKEA with pre-trained models [42, 25, 44, 28]. For MuKEA, we set the knowledge base size to the accumulated knowledge from VQA 2.0 [13] and OK-VQA [29]. The model size increases as the multimodal knowledge base size increases. Compared to ViLBERT, our model size only increases by 8.36% with the performance boost by 11.24%. The model size of KRISP is larger than ours by 86.78%, but its performance is inferior to ours by 3.69%. It indicates that our improvement is not from more parameters, but from the model structure.

Comparison on KRVQA: In Table 2, we compare MuKEA with traditional VQA models [38, 56, 2, 55] and the knowledge-based model [10]. ‘KB-not-related’ questions only require basic visual knowledge while ‘KB-related’ questions need
factual knowledge from knowledge bases.

Table 2 shows that although the ranking time is positively correlated with the size of knowledge base. It is relatively faster in the total inference time (less than 0.01%, as shown in the column of ‘Ranking/Inference’). Since the GPU uses threads to process matrix multiplication in parallel, ranking time is not linearly related to the size of knowledge base. Our model still has good efficiency based on large-scale multimodal knowledge base.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Ablation of key components in MuKEA on OK-VQA.
S4.T3.table:
Method Accuracy
1. MuKEA (full model) 42.59
Ablation of Loss Function
2. w/o ℒTrisubscriptℒTri\mathcal{L}_{\rm Tri} 41.35
3. w/o ℒSemsubscriptℒSem\mathcal{L}_{\rm Sem} 42.06
4. w/o ℒTrisubscriptℒTri\mathcal{L}_{\rm Tri} & ℒSemsubscriptℒSem\mathcal{L}_{\rm Sem} 40.84
5. w/o ℒTransEsubscriptℒTransE\mathcal{L}_{\rm TransE} 24.50
Ablation of Triplet Representation
6. head entity w/ soft-attention 40.67
7. relation w/ self-attention 40.79
8. tail entity w/ GloVe 41.42
Ablation of Triplet Structure
9. w/o hℎh 39.83
10.  w/o r𝑟r 39.40
Ablation of Knowledge Source
11.  w/o VQA 2.0 knowledge 36.35
12.  w/o OK-VQA knowledge 27.20
Ablation of Pre-training Knowledge
13.  w/o LXMERT pre-training 33.52
references: In Table 3, we evaluate the contribution of knowledge learning losses, knowledge extraction schema, and knowledge accumulation strategy in MuKEA on the OK-VQA dataset. (1) In models ‘2-5’, we evaluate the effect of each loss function on the performance. The accuracy of removing ℒTrisubscriptℒTri\mathcal{L}_{\rm Tri} and ℒSemsubscriptℒSem\mathcal{L}_{\rm Sem} respectively decreases by 1.24%percent\% and 0.53%percent\% while removing ℒTransEsubscriptℒTransE\mathcal{L}_{\rm TransE} results in a significant decrease in model ‘5’. Because ℒTransEsubscriptℒTransE\mathcal{L}_{\rm TransE} preserves the embedding structure of the whole triplets in our multimodal knowledge base, which has greater impact than ℒTrisubscriptℒTri\mathcal{L}_{\rm Tri} and ℒSemsubscriptℒSem\mathcal{L}_{\rm Sem}. Model ‘4’ results in a further decrease compared with ‘2’ and ‘3’, which indicates the complementary benefits of ℒTrisubscriptℒTri\mathcal{L}_{\rm Tri} and ℒSemsubscriptℒSem\mathcal{L}_{\rm Sem}. (2) In models ‘6-8’, we assess the influence of triplet extraction methods. For head entity extraction, we replace Gumbel-Softmax with soft attention in ‘6’ and the performance drops by 1.92%percent\%. It’s because that the head entity derived from LXMERT already contains object-centric contextual semantics for complex questions while directly fusing object features together introduces unexpected noise. Similarly, we apply self-attention over all the output tokens of LXMEART to represent the relation in ‘7’ and the accuracy decreases by 1.80%percent\% compared with using [CLS] token, which benefits from the the pre-training classification task to contain highly-correlated multimodal information. Furthermore, we utilize GloVe [37] to represent the tail entity in ‘8’, resulting in a 1.17%percent\% accuracy drop because of the heterogeneous gap between fixed word embeddings and multimodal triplet representations. (3) In models ‘9-10’, we prove the importance of triplet structure. We remove the head entity and the tail entity respectively. The performance drops 2.76% and 3.19% accordingly, which proves the effectiveness of our triplet-based knowledge organization structure. (4) In models ‘11-12’, we prove the importance of pre-training and fine-tuning strategy for knowledge accumulation. It’s obvious that without either of the two process, the performance decreases remarkably. Though the basic knowledge in VQA 2.0 is less influential than the domain-specific knowledge in OK-VQA, the two works together in a curriculum learning mode achieves the best performance. (5) In model ‘13’, we further test the influence of prior knowledge accumulated in the pre-trained LXMERT. The accuracy drops 9.07%percent\% without pre-training since both the head entity and the relation representations rely on the contextual information from the pre-trained knowledge.

Table 3 shows that our model achieves comparable results compared with state-of-the-art models. This is mainly due to the following reasons: (1) VQA 2.0 mainly relies on visual appearance clues instead of external knowledge. As shown in Figure 5, the example on the left requires the model to sense colors in multiple regions, while the example on the right requires the model to accurately detect object in the target region. (2) Existing models takes the head answers as the candidate answers, we accumulate multimodal knowledge on the whole dataset to ensure the diversity of answers, which is 10 times larger than the candidate answer set.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4: MuKEA accuracy on the failure subset of KB-based models (a) and vice versa (b). * indicates the model is re-implemented.
S4.T4.table:
Method Failure subset
MUTAN + AN∗ Mucko∗ KRISP∗
MuKEA 40.09 40.06 40.46
references: Table 4 shows the performance of MuKEA on the failure OK-VQA test subset of the above three models and vice versa. MuKEA consistently achieves over 40% accuracy on all the failure cases of the KB-based models (Table 4(a)). Meanwhile, KB-based models obtain over 26% accuracy on questions difficult for MuKEA (Table 4(b)). It proves that multimodal knowledge and existing KB knowledge respectively covers different types of open-ended questions.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Performance of model ensemble on OK-VQA.
S4.T5.table:
Method Accuracy
MuKEA 42.59
MUTAN + AN∗ 25.43
MuKEA + (MUTAN + AN∗) 35.39
MuKEA + (MUTAN + AN∗) oracle 43.64
Mucko∗ 27.17
MuKEA + Mucko∗ 35.97
MuKEA + Mucko∗ oracle 44.84
KRISP∗ 32.02
MuKEA + KRISP∗ 37.75
MuKEA + KRISP∗ oracle 47.15
references: We further assemble MuKEA with three models respectively: if the difference of the top 2 minimum distances predicted by Eq. 10 is larger than a threshold m𝑚m (m=0.07𝑚0.07m=0.07), we select the predicted answer of MuKEA, otherwise, selecting the other. In Table 5, the baseline models are respectively improved by 9.96%percent\%, 8.80%percent\% and 5.73%percent\% after model ensemble. We also present the oracle setting that takes the accurate prediction from either of the models as the answer. The oracle performance obtains significant improvement, which further proves the complementary benefits of multimodal knowledge and existing knowledge bases.

S4.T6.caption: Table 6: Long-tail analysis on OK-VQA dataset.
S4.T6.table:
Method Accuracy mAccuracy
KRISP∗ 32.31 26.91
MuKEA 42.59 35.42
references: To prove the model’s generalization ability on the rare answers while not overfitting on the ‘head’ ones, we propose a new unbiased metric mean Accuracy (mAccuracy) to fairly evaluate the performance on the long-tail distributed answers. Inspired by the unbiased metric in scene graph generation [11, 45], mAccuracy calculates the accuracy for each unique answer separately and average for all the answers. We compare MuKEA with KRISP, which demonstrates its great generalization ability by referring to multiple knowledge sources. In Table 6, our model greatly outperforms KRISP by 8.51% on mAccuracy, which proves the strong generalization ability of the multimodal knowledge on the long-tail knowledge without sacrificing the accuracy of frequent referred knowledge.
